title: How to Plant and Care for Pampas Grass

steps.title: Plant pampas grass in spring.
steps.content: Plant pampas grass in spring. [2] X Expert Source Maggie Moran Home & Garden Specialist Expert Interview. Your grass will need lots of sun, and only a small amount of water, so planting in fall or winter months could hinder your grass’s growth. [3] X Research source Because pampas grass grows so large, it grows better outside in the lawn or garden, rather than in containers. Due to its size and also the sharpness of its leaves, it does not make a good indoor plant.

steps.title: Choose a location.
steps.content: Choose a location. You’ll want a spot with plenty of room as pampas grass grows tall as well as spreads wide. Choose an area with full sun to partial shade. [4] X Expert Source Maggie Moran Home & Garden Specialist Expert Interview. Locations receiving at least 6 hours of sunlight daily are best for maximum growth. [5] X Research source This grass can grow to be over 10 ft (3 m) tall. It makes for an excellent natural fence. Do not place pampas grass near roadways or driveways; the tall and bushy grass can interfere with lines of sight. The plant should also not be placed too close to central air conditioning units as the long leaves can become caught in the fans. Pampas grass leaves have sharp edges, so avoid planting in an area where young children play.

steps.title: Prepare the soil.
steps.content: Prepare the soil. Pampas grass grows best in areas with well-drained, fertile soil. Till the soil to aerate it then add an organic compost, peat moss, or manure to help fertilize the grass. Choose a loamy variety to ensure the soil will drain well. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Plant seeds.
steps.content: Plant seeds. If you’d like to plant seeds rather than young plants, sow them directly onto the prepared soil. They need light to germinate, so don’t cover them with soil. You can, however, rake the area lightly to prevent the seeds from blowing away or being eaten by birds. Water very lightly to ensure the seeds don’t wash away. [7] X Research source Seeds take between 20 and 25 days to germinate.

steps.title: Use young plants.
steps.content: Use young plants. Alternatively, you can plant young pampas grass instead of starting with seeds. Starting with young plants helps your pampas grass establish itself as well as grow quickly. You can find young pampas grass plants at many nurseries, garden shops, and even hardware stores. If you can’t find it locally, order it online.

steps.title: Dig holes.
steps.content: Dig holes. Using a shovel, dig holes that are three times as wide and three times as deep as the root system on your young pampas grass plant. This will give the roots room to spread and establish themselves. This species grows rapidly, so you’ll need to place holes at least 6 ft (1.8 m) apart if planting multiple clumps of pampas grass. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Spread the roots apart.
steps.content: Spread the roots apart. Use your hands to gently separate the root ball. This will help your roots take hold in the soil as well as absorb moisture more easily. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Place the plant in the hole.
steps.content: Place the plant in the hole. Gently position the plant so that it is upright in the middle of the hole. Backfill the dirt around the plant. You can add sand to the soil if your chosen area does not drain well. Gently pat down the dirt or sand to ensure the plant is placed sturdily.

steps.title: Water deeply and immediately.
steps.content: Water deeply and immediately. Give your newly-planted pampas grass lots of water to ensure the soil is seated and that the plant will take root. You should keep the soil evenly moist until your pampas grass has established itself. [10] X Expert Source Grant Wallace Landscaper Expert Interview. 6 December 2022. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Water sparingly.
steps.content: Water sparingly. Pampas grass can thrive in many conditions, and will adapt to its location. You need only water the ornamental grass once every couple of weeks for the first year of growth. Water more frequently during periods of extreme drought. No watering is needed after the plant is well established. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Fertilize the grass.
steps.content: Fertilize the grass. During the first year, fertilize up to three times. After the first year, fertilize only once per year. Use a high-quality garden fertilizer to enhance the beauty of the flowers. [13] X Expert Source Grant Wallace Landscaper Expert Interview. 6 December 2022. [14] X Research source It may take up to three years for your pampas grass to flower.

steps.title: Prune established pampas grass.
steps.content: Prune established pampas grass. [15] X Expert Source Grant Wallace Landscaper Expert Interview. 6 December 2022. c Use trimmers to prune your grass in the late winter or early spring months. You can also tie a piece of rope around the plant, about 4 ft (1.2 m) from the ground and use a power weed trimmer to cut the grass. Remove all the foliage and flower stalks above 12 in (30 cm) in height. [16] X Research source Be careful and wear long sleeves and gloves when pruning and handling your pampas grass plants as the edges are sharp. Cut through the clumps after pruning to divide them. The sliced clump can then be planted elsewhere.

steps.title: Drain the leaves.
steps.content: Drain the leaves. Tie the leaves of the grass together with string in November to allow water to drain from the plant. This will prevent shock during the cold months.

steps.title: Cover the roots.
steps.content: Cover the roots. If you live in an area where temperatures dip below freezing, you’ll want to put straw or mulch over the roots of your pampas grass before frost season. Alternatively, you can cover the roots with a fleece wrap.

steps.title: Keep an eye out for diseases and pests.
steps.content: Keep an eye out for diseases and pests. Luckily, pampas grass is almost entirely disease-free. However, pampas grass can occasionally develop spots. Simply use a fungicide to quickly get rid it. Pampas grass is also rarely eaten by animals, but it can serve as a great habitat for them. Because of this, it’s a good idea to search your pampas grass from time to time to ensure that no unwanted guests are residing inside.
